item.title: Predict YouTube Video Popularity with Twitter's Feed
item.description:
Excerpt:

We predict viewcount jumps and early viewcounts of YouTube videos, which are mission impossible for former methods (without external information).

by Honglin Yu, Lexing Xie and Scott Sanner

Motivation

  • Online social networks are far not isolated islands. Understanding their interaction has both commercial and research values.
  • With the help of external information, we can better predict YouTube video popularity.
  • Treating viewcount changes as a measure, we can understand what kinds of tweeting patterns truely indicate the popularity of things mentioned in tweets.

Problem Setup

We proposed two prediction problems which are mission impossible without external information:

  • Predict videos' viewcount right after uploading (
    Early
    )
  • Predict whether videos' viewcount suddenly increase (
    Jump
    )

Result Highlights (Demo)

Here are two examples of showing clear correlation between tweets pulses and viewcount increases. For more details about our results (i.e. performances of each features), please look at our poster or paper.

Twitter Features Highlights

  • User graph features: degree, pagerank and hub/authority scores computed from a Twitter user graph of 41.7 million nodes and 1.47 billion edges.
  • User behavior features: the frequencies of their usage and engagement of hashtag, retweeting etc. extracted from 476 million tweets.

Software Highlights

  • YTcrawl : a powerful YouTube viewcount history crawler.
  • Programs (in C++) to efficiently compute centrality scores (mainstream tools like NetworkX or iGraph do not work due to the huge size of the graph).
  • Various programs/scripts to efficiently do feature engineering.

Conclusions

  • Our work confirms that Twitter information can be effectively used to predict video popularity on YouTube.
  • Twitter user features associated with tweeting activities are more informative than graph features. Having a diverse range of users and associated tweeting activities is more informative than the total or average volume of activity of these users.

Posters

For more details, please see the poster.

item.title: Visual Meme Sequence Analysis on YouTube (Video Remix Analysis)
item.description:
Excerpt:

Mining visual meme sequences from large number of videos

by Honglin Yu and Lexing Xie

Motivation

Many YouTube videos are remix videos which consist of shots copied from other videos. Former work built system trying to find out duplicate shots in large number of videos. This work aims to further take the association rules and orders of shots into consideration. The motivation of this work are,

  • "Order" of shots is crucially important for video making (see Montage, Kuleshov Effect)
  • Enable viral content analysis at shot sequence level
  • Try to understand human video editing preference, w.r.t. different topics

System Overview

We have built the following system to find visual meme sequences.

Result

Here is an example of the mining results (22.5MB). Every row is the shots for each video in chronological order. And the black lines connect the visual memes we found. (These videos are about 2009 Iranian election protests)

Software Developed

  • ShotDetect: detect shots of videos
    • It is fast, deveploped by C++ and is directly based on libavcodec and openCV etc.
    • It can deal with all formats of online videos (thanks to libavcodec etc.)
    • The performace is quite good (F1 score > 80% from a test on 400 shots)
  • PySW: implement Smith-Waterman Algorithms for sub-sequence matching (written in C++, wrapped in python)
  • Various powerful parallel crawling and preprocessing programs
    • Deployed on The National Computational Infrastructure
    • Processed > 15TB data
